citation.article-title: Pseudovibrio denitrificans gen. nov., sp. nov., a marine, facultatively anaerobic, fermentative bacterium capable of denitrification
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pseudovibrio denitrificans sp. nov.
Pseudovibrio denitrificans (de.ni.tri′fi.cans. N.L. v. denitrifico to denitrify; N.L. part. adj. denitrificans denitrifying).
Description is as for the genus with the following additional characteristics.
Irregular rod-shaped cells, approximately 2·0–4·5 μm long by 0·6–0·8 μm wide.
Colonies produced on plate media are circular, translucent and non-luminescent, with an entire margin.
Capable of complete denitrification, i.e. capable of reducing to N2 via and N2O.
Able to ferment glucose, mannose, sucrose and trehalose with production of acid but no gas.
Unable to ferment d-arabinose, cellobiose, dulcitol, glycerol, inositol, lactose, mannitol, sorbitol or xylose.
Optimal growth occurs at about 30 °C, pH 8 and 3 % NaCl.
Unable to grow at 42 °C or at 8–10 % NaCl.
Major cellular fatty acids are 2-OH-14 : 0, 3-OH-14 : 0 and 16 : 0.
Resistant to the vibriostatic agent O/129 at 10 and 150 μg.
DNase, gelatinase and lipase tests are positive, but agarase, amylase, arginine dihydrolase and lysine and ornithine decarboxylase tests are negative.
H2S is not produced from thiosulphate.
Galactose, glucose, mannose, sucrose and trehalose can be utilized as sole carbon and energy sources, but cellobiose, lactose, xylose, dulcitol and mannitol can not.

Susceptible to ampicillin (10 μg), carbenicillin (100 μg), cephalothin (30 μg), chloramphenicol (30 μg), erythromycin (15 μg), neomycin (30 μg), novobiocin (30 μg) and vancomycin (30 μg); intermediate susceptibility to nalidixic acid (30 μg) and tetracycline (30 μg); resistant to clindamycin (2 μg), colistin (10 μg), gentamicin (10 μg), lincomycin (2 μg), penicillin G (10 U), polymyxin B (300 U) and streptomycin (10 μg).
Strain DN34T has a DNA G+C content of 51·7 mol%.
